title: How to Grow African Hair Faster and Longer

steps.title: Determine your hair type.
steps.content: Determine your hair type. A salon employee or online advice can help you find the characteristics of your hair. This will help you choose the right treatments and products. Here's the basic breakdown: Wavy hair (type 2), generally thin and easy to handle Curly hair (type 3) Coily hair (type 4), usually very fragile and hard to grow out

steps.title: Wash your hair only when you must.
steps.content: Wash your hair only when you must. Washing hair too often strips it of natural oils. Try washing it once a week. Switch to once every two or three weeks if your hair starts to break easily. [1] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Try to find a shampoo that doesn't leave your hair feeling too dry. To reduce damage, wash hair in lukewarm water and rinse in cool water. [2] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Let hair dry on its own.
steps.content: Let hair dry on its own. The heat from blow-drying can cause damage, leading your hair to break before it grows to the desired length. [3] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Instead, plait your hair, wrap it in a silk scarf, and let dry overnight. Alternatively, towel dry your hair by wrapping it in a towel and simply rubbing your head for a while. [4] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Use conditioner each time you wash.
steps.content: Use conditioner each time you wash. Shampoo strips your hair of natural oils. Restore these with conditioner suited for African hair. [5] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Periodically deep condition your hair as well. You can use a leave-in conditioner in between washes.

steps.title: Apply hair oil daily.
steps.content: Apply hair oil daily. Rub natural oil into the middle and ends of your hair to make it soft and supple. This will help prevent it from breaking before it grows too long. Jamaican oil, castor oil, Moroccan oil, or lavender oil are all good options. [6] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Covering your hair with a satin scarf can help your hair take in the oil. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Moisturize.
steps.content: Moisturize. Water strengthens dry hair and may stimulate your hair roots. You can apply water, moisturizing conditioner, or a mixture of half olive oil or half coconut oil. For extra moisture, apply each one, in that order. The oil will help seal in the moisture. [8] X Research source If you use gel or mousse in your hairstyle, try hair jam instead. This will hold your hair, then eventually melt into oils to add shine and moisture.

steps.title: Consider protein conditioner.
steps.content: Consider protein conditioner. These can strengthen some types of hair but may damage dry hair. Try brushing your hair: if your strands stretch significantly before breaking, you may need more protein. [9] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Do not leave in protein conditioner longer than instructed on the label, or it may turn hard and brittle.

steps.title: Grease your scalp when dry.
steps.content: Grease your scalp when dry. About every other day or when your scalp feels dry, apply coconut grease to the tip of your pointer finger. Apply at the top of your part and sweep back until all the grease has been applied. [10] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Stop if you notice dandruff, as oil can feed the fungus that causes it. If you have a perm, grease only once a week, or apply hot oil instead.

steps.title: Remove products with neutralizing shampoo.
steps.content: Remove products with neutralizing shampoo. Once a month, use a neutralizing shampoo to clean all products out of your hair. If you use a lot of sprays, gels, and other styling products, use it every other week. [11] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Take vitamins.
steps.content: Take vitamins. Vitamin supplements can give your hair the nutrients they need to grow faster and stronger.

steps.title: Eat enough protein.
steps.content: Eat enough protein. Eat food with plenty of protein, such as avocado, pumpkin seeds, or gelatin. [12] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Protect the ends of your hair.
steps.content: Protect the ends of your hair. Leaving your hair down can make your hair vulnerable to breakage. Put your hair in a bun , braids , or other styles that keeps your ends tucked away. Fasten your hairdo with bobby pins, since elastic bands can rip out your hair. [13] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Trim damaged hair.
steps.content: Trim damaged hair. Trim the ends of your hair every two weeks, or whenever they start to split. If your hair is healthy, you may only need to remove 1–2 inches (2.5–5cm) every three or four months. It may seem odd to trim your hair to help it grow, but it really does help. Split ends rapidly lead to breakage, making it very hard to grow your hair out. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Don't abuse your hair.
steps.content: Don't abuse your hair. Blow drying, flat irons, over-tight braiding or weaves, over-processing, dye, and perms ruin your hair. This can cause damage and breakage, so use them as little as possible.
